Award.AwardTitle: Undergraduate Sustainable Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics (U-S2TEM) Scholars

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The intellectual merit of the Undergraduate Training in the Environment (UTE) Scholars program derives from its focus on the impacts of global changes and the dynamics and sustainability of natural and human built systems. The UTE Scholars program supports 14 students in the Colleges of Science, Mines and Earth Science, and Engineering who work as a multidisciplinary cohort to explore how various scientific and engineering fields interact. This scholarship program is a partnership of the University of Utah's Global Change and Sustainability Center (GCSC) and the Center for Science and Math Education (CSME). This partnership provides academically talented and financially challenged undergraduate students with unique educational and research opportunities. The program also provides academic scaffolding, mentoring, professional development, and supports them throughout their undergraduate training.

The broader impacts of the UTE Scholars program derive from partnerships with various and diverse organizations both in recruiting and outreach. These partnerships engage scholars in outreach to the minority-majority school districts as well as rural areas. The UTE Scholars seminar series provides a forum for participants to learn to integrate research activities with education in order to place their science in a broader societal context. This scholarship project is developing an interdisciplinary learning community of students, faculty, and professionals that synergistically engages and supports the UTE Scholars as they move through their academic training. Further, this program provides a model for similar programs in the future both within and outside of the University of Utah.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a significant national need for undergraduates trained in environmental fields to address the challenges of today and tomorrow. We worked to address this need through development of the Undergraduate Sustainability STEM (U-S2TEM) Scholars at the University of Utah. The U-S2TEM Scholars program is led by a diverse team of engineering and science researchers who focus on the impacts of global changes on the dynamics and sustainability of natural and human built systems. The program is a partnership of the University of Utah’s Global Change and Sustainability Center (GCSC) and the Center for Science and Math Education (CSME) to provide academically talented and financially challenged undergraduate students with unique educational and research opportunities. Through the 5 years of this program, we recruited, supported, and mentored 21 undergraduates during their time at the University of Utah. The U-S2TEM Scholars interacted with the faculty leaders through mentoring, seminars, and courses designed to build an intellectual learning community that enhances the scholars’ educational development, and research opportunities.  The students successfully worked towards B.S. degrees in environmental science and engineering while U-S2TEM provided financial support, mentoring, and career opportunities.  The leaders mindfully fostered a supportive intellectual and social environment engaging in many diverse and intellectually stimulating activities including professional development, seminar programs, field trips, interdisciplinary research discussions, facility demonstrations, community outreach, and more.  The students had many opportunities to grow their professional networks, participate in peer to peer mentoring, graduate student to undergraduate mentoring, and faculty to student mentoring.  Activities were created initially for the whole group, and then individually as their careers developed.  We shared successes via social media (such as Facebook and Twitter) and internally to the University community through reporting of the Global Change and Sustainability Center. The students were able to gain experience exploring sustainability concepts that they would not have had exposure to otherwise.  Students provided feedback sharing how U-S2TEM "provided [them] with valuable experience and increased [their] confidence of making positive change within interdisciplinary communities." They gave the program recognition for "giving [them] the opportunity to learn more about sustainability and how that can relate back to [their] interests or areas of study."  One student shared that "the most helpful part of U- S2TEM was the guidance and support that the program as a whole and the mentors provided at the beginning of my college career. It provided resources, relationships and insight that is rare to find on such a large campus. I would attribute a large portion of my success in college to the S2TEM program and the mentors."
